DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian Dissident in U.S. for Cancer Treatment
DOC.TEXT: The wife of Ukrainian dissident Mikhailo Horyn was being treated in the United States on Monday after 105 members of Congress asked Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to give her a temporary exit visa. Olha Horyn, who arrived in the United States on Saturday, had applied for a temporary visa seven months ago. She did not immediately get it despite a new Soviet law that guarantees a decision on medical visa requests within three days, said Rep. Louise Slaughter, D-N.Y. Slaughter sent the letter, signed by 104 colleagues, Nov. 8. Mrs. Horyn had applied for a visa after receiving an offer of free medical treatment from St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. The care she will receive there over the next three months is not available in the Soviet Union, said Bozhena Olshaniwsky, president of Americans for Human Rights in the Ukraine. Mrs. Horyn had a radical mastectomy 10 years ago, but is suffering back pain that may indicate the cancer has returned, Olshaniwsky said. Olshaniwsky said she believed Mrs. Horyn's visa was blocked because of her and her husband's political activity. Mikhailo Horyn, a former political prisoner, is general secretary of the Ukrainian national movement, Rukh, and the brother of dissident leader Bogdan Horyn. Mikhailo Horyn is a candidate for a seat in the Ukrainian parliament.
